Dromedaries are camels, though.
so are lamas
Only talking about camels (Camelus genus), which has 3 species, not the Camelidae family that includes llamas and others.

I do support thou on that. Because the species that we see in the game, are only of the dromedary of the genus camel, where also the Bactrian camel is. It just happens to be that the Bactrian camel is so typical and prominenet that it has become the main species in the genus.

So it is true that this new animal is in the genus Camelus, but I really think that we should name it after what species it is, and not what genus it belongs to. Because i do not think that players are going to be conscious about that the name would be for the camelid genus, (wich is a part of the family Camelidae), when they see this bright long-legged ungulate with a singel hump. I would think that players would unconsciously expect to see the name of the species of the mobs they see. 

There are already some confusion to what the difference between the species camel and the species dromadary is in some languages like English, so i do not think that it would be any good that players in all ages using the English language in game, to get the name of the genus, or a completely different species, constantly displayed as the name for this specific species. They are different enough and are evolved for different climates. But there are possible to breed two closely related species, like horses and donkies, or lions and tigers. But that does not make them the same species.

Title: ‚ÄúEvents in minecraft‚Äù

They probably didn‚Äôt have that stuff planed. Even more serious companies like Nintendo add stuff last minute or put it in a later update.
Then people will complain that everything in the update was spoiled. Remember 1.13?

Not everything is announced at Minecon or Minecraft Live. Other features are added eventually, similar to the Minecraft Tricky Trials update.

  • Raw copper was never mentioned in Minecraft Live 2020.
  • Tuff slabs were never mentioned at Minecraft Live 2023.

The current copy/paste limit of 64 chunks in Minecraft Bedrock makes it really hard to move big builds between worlds. Third‚Äëparty tools that used to help are now paid, so transferring massive structures is even harder.

Please consider increasing the limit so players can move large projects more easily. Thanks.
I like it to be on xbox

The Bedrock Editor is more of a development tool (or Creator Tool as referred by Mojang) than a game that should be available on console storefronts. In addition it has so many functions and features that require having a vast number of inputs that consoles simply do not support. The Editor is also a heavy, resource intensive application which would make it difficult to run on lower-end devices, most likely including the 8th and 9th generation of consoles, and most mobile devices. A version for macOS, iPadOS, & Linux are is the most realistic platforms that The Bedrock Editor could and should support.
Or a java editor would be cool, because mac can only use java (idk why mac can use bedrock)
I love your idea if people had Bedrock Editor they could make modifications to the worlds that they want.
You already have world edit.
There could also be special scripting APIs made in Java or Javascript for the Minecraft Java Editor.

Java already has so many community offered resources that help with game modification which Bedrock does not have. Creating a Java Editor when the game's source code is as exposed as it already is would simply be a waste of resources.
